titles.title: A Dataset for Metaphor Detection in Early Medieval Hebrew Poetry

posterContent.posterTitle: A Dataset for Metaphor Detection in Early Medieval Hebrew Poetry

sections.sectionContent: The corpus of late antique and medieval Hebrew is vast and represents a crucial linguistic and cultural bridge between Biblical and modern Hebrew. Poetry is prominent in texts from these time periods and one of its characteristics is the use of metaphor. Distinguishing figurative and literal words or phrases is a major task for scholars in the Humanities, especially in the fields of literature, linguistics, and hermeneutics. We present a new, challenging dataset of early medieval Hebrew poetry with expert annotations of metaphors with baseline results.

• Early medieval Hebrew poems.
• 180 labeled texts, 7,000 sentences, 45,000 words.
• 15% of the words are metaphors.
Inter-annotator agreement evaluates how consistently different annotators label data for NLP research (measured in Cohen's kappa). The score for our dataset is 0.618 (considered substantial).

Language models (pre-trained & adapted)

*Project Ben-Yehuda is a volunteer-based online library of free Hebrew literature.

• AlephBERT is outperformed by AlephBERT Adapted.
• BEREL, pre-trained on medieval texts, shows the best results.
